hello@moondigitaldesign.co.uk.post_text:
Design plays a role far beyond first impressions. When applied strategically, it supports the full customer journey, from the moment someone discovers your brand to the point where trust and loyalty are built.

1. Discovery is where credibility is established.
Strong visual identity, clear positioning, and consistent branding help users immediately understand who you are, what you offer, and why you are worth paying attention to.

2. Engagement keeps interest alive.
Thoughtful layouts, readable typography, and intuitive navigation reduce friction and encourage users to explore more pages, content, or services.

3. Conversion depends on clarity.
Clear calls-to-action, focused page structure, and well-designed user flows help people make confident decisions without confusion or hesitation.

4. Retention is shaped by consistency.
A cohesive experience across platforms, on-brand communication, and easy-to-use systems reinforce familiarity and long-term trust.

How intentionally is your design supporting every stage of your customer journey?

Reality can be sad and humbling sometimes even with the greatest of efforts.

I'm Kensley Kulani Mbungele and this is my story. Even after taking a bold decision to take out a Standard bank student loan amounting to R86 888 to pay for my 2nd year fees in order to be cleared to register for my 3rd year, after successfully completing that 3rd year i still find myself in R19 315 of outstanding fees which has resulted in graduating(Diploma in Mechanical Engineering) without my qualification in September 2025.

After graduating i started applying for Internships and other entry level positions with the hopes of finding something soon to could pay towards my outstanding fees on my own and be able to register for my Advanced Diploma this 2026, but reality has not the been the movie scripted in my head. Honestly,Â  being a secondary school teacher is one of the best jobs in the world. 

It is a rare profession that allows you to indulge yourself in talking about the subject you love day in and day out! 

In the classroom, you have the freedom to be as creative and imaginative as you want, working with autonomy, yet always having the support of your team, a group of people who love the same subject as you, right behind you. 

Beyond your subject you know that you are making a difference to young people every single day. Often, most significantly, having the biggest impact on the students you might think you arenâ€™t reaching at allâ€¦

People dismiss teaching as a career too quickly. This is why we are so proud to be running the DfE â€˜Get Into Teachingâ€™ Internship Programme again. It is a brilliant way to get paid to experience life in school and decide if teaching is the right path for you. 

If you are an undergraduate in your second, third or final year of study or studying for a Masterâ€™s degree in any ofÂ  the following subjects: Maths, Physics, Chemistry, Computing, Design & Technology or a Modern Foreign Language, and are even just thinking about teaching in the future, please get in touch. 

The placements are for three weeks and will take place from Monday 22nd June until Friday 10th July 2026. Â Interns will be paid Â£455 per week. 

Applications are now open and can be completed online: https://lnkd.in/e-ukvaMF

info@vlsiforall.com.post_text:
VLSI Design Conference 2026 â€“ Day 4 Highlights âœ¨

Day 4 of the VLSI Design Conference was all about meaningful interactions, learning, and connecting with some incredibly talented students from premium engineering institutions across India. It was inspiring to see such enthusiasm and curiosity among the next generation of VLSI and semiconductor engineers.

I had the opportunity to interact with students and Faculties from leading colleges in Pune, including MKSSS Cummins College of Engineering for Women, Dr. D. Y. Patil Institute of Technology, Pimpri, Pune, COEP Technological University, Vishwakarma Institute Of Technology, MIT World Peace University, SIT- Symbiosis Institute of Technology, and several other reputed institutions. Each interaction reflected strong technical interest and a growing passion for VLSI design and semiconductor careers.

It was equally great to meet students from institutions outside Pune as well, such as National Institute of Technology, Tiruchirappalli, Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT), Nagpur, IIIT Nagpur, Vellore Institute of Technology, Chennai Institute of Technology, and many more colleges from different regions of the country. Discussions ranged from career pathways in VLSI, skills required for the semiconductor industry, internships and research opportunities, to industry expectations from fresh graduates.

Interacting with such motivated students reaffirmed the importance of platforms like VLSID, which bring together industry, academia, and students on a single stage to enable learning, mentorship, and collaboration. Looking forward to seeing many of these students become future contributors to Indiaâ€™s growing semiconductor ecosystem. ğŸš€
